**Context:** I was writing `{ somearray.into_iter().fold( . . . ) }` however missed a semi-colon. But, instead of rustc looking at it started complaining for the logic inside `.fold()`. Here is the picture:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29653551/180055260-4dbda494-fa77-4d1c-9694-bff55287cbb2.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29653551/180055404-d7d82a21-753e-44a0-9043-45518c674c30.png)

**Proposal:** I was thinking if we could prioritize on catching whether some user accidentally "returned" something inside a for loop instead of reporting correct things as incorrect.

**Min. reproducible example**:
```rust
for _ in 0..1 {
    true
}
```
With error:
```rustc
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:3:5
  |
3 |     true
  |     ^^^^ expected `()`, found `bool`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0308`.
```
Even though the error here looks somewhat appropriate, we can however be almost always sure that the user missed a semi-colon.
